data.title: Skip deleted directories when restoring application windows
data.body:
Refs #10628
Closes #11032

@jrkoenig I understand your original PR #10628 better now and after considering some alternatives, I think your idea of making `initialPaths` explicit is our best option. I cherry-picked that commit and fixed merge conflicts, along with some other small changes that I needed to get a clean restoration experience. Without these changes, I was getting a spurious entry for a parent directory in my project paths.

Can you give this a try and make sure I haven't missed some case that's important to you?

data.title: Add config option for MRU tabs
data.body:
### Prerequisites
- [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging#check-if-the-problem-shows-up-in-safe-mode)?
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging)?
- [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?
### Description
#10737 made ctrl+tabbing MRU-based, but did not offer a config option to revert to the existing left->right behavior.  Given that this is a very significant change to default behavior, we should keep the old sequential behavior as the default switching technique and expose MRU tabbing through its own setting.

/cc @natalieogle, @benogle
### Versions

You can get this information from executing `atom --version` and `apm --version` at the command line.

```
Atom    : 1.7.0-dev-6beed1d
Electron: 0.36.8
Chrome  : 47.0.2526.110
Node    : 5.1.1
```

data.title: Implement accessibility info at Mac OS X
data.body:
In OS X native text editing apps provide information about the edited text using the accessibility methods. It allows other application to communicate with the application.

Currently Atom does not support anything like that. Including the beta version.

Here is an example. On the screenshot, there is _TextMate_ (popular programmer editor) window and _Accessibility Inspector_ (displays information provided by other applications using accessibility).

The most interesting values are AXValue (editing content) and AXSelectedTextRange (range of the selected text.)

![accessibility](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/868275/13474673/683b6baa-e0bf-11e5-8a92-044750990f51.png)

data.title: Use persistence stateKey directly rather than initialPaths
data.body:
Saves and restores application state using the stateKey rather than initialPaths themselves. This avoids having Atom "open" these initialPaths, instead using the deserialized project to restore these paths.

Replaces #10628, see #11023

spec/integration/startup-spec.coffee should have a spec for this, but I couldn't get the tests to run.

data.title: Problem with ampersand in folder name
data.body:
### Description
- When a folder has an ampersand in the name and you right click and choose "Show in Explorer" it returns the following warning:

> Opening folder in Explorer failed
> 'Test' is not recognized as an internal or external command,
> operable program or batch file.

_("Test' is everything after the &)_
- If you choose a file within that folder Atom return the following warning:

> Opening file in Explorer failed
> The system can not find the path specified.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Click a folder with an & in the name
2. Right click on the folder and choose "Show in Explorer".

**Expected behavior:** Atom opens the folder in explorer

**Actual behavior:** Atom opens the parent folder and returns an error
### Versions

**Atom version:** 1.5.3
**OS and version:** Windows 10

data.title: Weird behavior regarding backslashes and merging quotes and parentheses
data.body:
### Description

Not sure if I'm using the right term for this: when you type a `(` into Atom, it automatically fills in the other one, so that your file now looks like `()`. If you then type a `)`, this character is merged into the other one, so that you don't accidentally do this: `())`. This feature is available for `"` as well.

This merging does not occur if a `)` or `"` is typed directly after a backslash, which I assume is because a backslash is often used to escape these characters as literals. What doesn't make sense is that merging does not occur on the subsequent character, either: so typing `(\z)` on your keyboard renders `(\z))` in your file. This is especially annoying when it comes to strings, because something like `"\n"` will become `"\n""` unless the user is specifically wary of this bug.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Open a new file
2. Type (as in, literally hit these keys) `(\z)`

**Expected behavior:** The file to contain `(\z)`

**Actual behavior:** File contains `(\z))`
### Versions

atom 1.5.3, apm 1.6.0

data.title: Pop-up message/warning when trying to open large files...
data.body:
It would be helpful if Atom would show a pop-up message requesting confirmation upon opening large files.

I'm sure that I'm not the only one that has accidentally clicked on a very large file (mp3, mp4, etc) and watched Atom nearly halt while trying to load it.

Ideally, Atom would read the file size of the item to open and would pop-up a confirmation request for any file past a certain size. 

Thank you!

data.title: move templates to ./github folder to declutter root
Move to new pane [enhancement] [ux]
data.body:
### Description

Maybe my work pattern is strange, but almost 100% of the time when I want a new pane (i.e. to split) I want to _move_ an _existing_ buffer to that new pane. Not duplicate it, and not create an empty pane.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Split pane right
2. Oh. Not what I wanted.
3. Move buffer to new pane

**Expected behavior:** I don't expect, but I desire the buffer to move to the newly created pane.

**Actual behavior:** The newly created pane is either empty, or the focussed buffer is opened there as well as remaining in existing pane.

Suggestion is to add 'split and move pane right/left/up/down'.
### Versions

``` sh
atom 1.5.3
apm  1.6.0
npm  2.13.3
node 0.10.40
python 2.7.10
git 2.7.2
```

data.title: Whitespace not showing after backspacing from start of previous line
data.body:
### Description

With Invisible Characters enabled, after backspacing from a previous line, whitespace is not displayed.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Enabled Invisible Characters
2. Write two indented lines, and position your mouse cursor at the beginning of the second line
   ![screen shot 2016-03-01 at 11 40 38 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6612067/13440224/dc90cd8a-dfa5-11e5-9a66-2ac49cbc8855.png)
3. Press backspace.
   ![screen shot 2016-03-01 at 11 40 54 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6612067/13440242/f47fc2fc-dfa5-11e5-9ff4-ef6e8a63bff7.png)

**Expected behavior:** Invisible whitespace characters show up as dots.

**Actual behavior:** Invisible whitespace characters do not show up at all.
### Versions

1.5.4

data.title: Atom should respect OS X standard file locations
data.body:
Atom is not making full use of the standard file storage locations/conventions on OS X. OS X provides standard locations for storing configuration, data and cache files. Those location should be used instead of the  `~/.atom/` folder. Most of the items found in `~/.atom/` should be moved to `~/Library/Application Support/Atom/`.

The following files should be moved to `~/Library/Application Support/Atom/`:
- `blob-store`
- `config.cson`
- `dev`
- `init.coffee`
- `keymap.cson`
- `packages`
- `snippets.cson`
- `storage`
- `styles.less`

The following files should be moved to `~/Library/Caches/Atom/`:
- `compile-cache`
- `Cache` (move from `~/Library/Application Support/Atom/`)
- `GPUCache` (move from `~/Library/Application Support/Atom/`)

data.title: Atom hangs when an opened file is written to
data.body:
### Prerequisites
- [ X ] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging#check-if-the-problem-shows-up-in-safe-mode)?
- [ X ] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [ X ] Did you check the [debugging guide](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging)?
- [ X ] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [ X ] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [ X ] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide.
### Description

Atom beta hangs when an open file is clobbered and continuously written to
### Steps to Reproduce

```
touch out.txt
atom-beta --safe out.txt
(for i in $(seq 100000); do echo "yyyyyyyyyy"; done) > out.txt
```

**Expected behavior:** [What you expected to happen]

atom changes to new file, and continues to work (atom stable does handle this fine)

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happened]

The two 'atom helper' processes hit > 260% CPU, and stay there. Eventually I am asked if I want to "keep waiting"
### Versions

You can get this information from executing `atom --version` and `apm --version` at the command line.

```
bash-4.3$ atom-beta --version
a1.6.0-beta6
bash-4.3$ apm-beta --version
apm  1.6.0
npm  2.13.3
node 0.10.40
python 2.7.11
git 2.7.2
```

data.title: Autoscroll after consolidating selections
data.body: This PR picks up on @colllin's #9642, merging it into master, simplifying tests, and fixing a core bug that was breaking its functionality. Manually tested and it works.

data.title: Always strip git+ prefix and .git suffix from package repository URLs
data.body:
Fixes https://github.com/atom/deprecation-cop/issues/66

Previously, a guard based on the presence of the `_id` field (which is inserted by npm during installation) prevented a regex replacement of the git+ prefix on URLs. Now we always do this. Since the .git suffix also causes problems and weâ€™re removing that in packages, I now remove that as well.

The result should be that deprecation cop doesn't need to perform its own normalization. This was the intended original behavior but the `_id` guard broke it.

data.title: Files opened from search results are treated as pending?
data.body:
On 920d348014ac2ddf42e54e0bed6bb2cd71465146.
1. Find in Project.
2. Click on a result.
3. The result opens in a new tab. Note that the tab name isn't in italics, so it doesn't appear to be pending.
4. Find in Project again for a different thing.
5. The result replaces the tab opened in (3).

If I save or double-click the tab name, it seems to clear the pending state as I'd expect.

/cc @BinaryMuse @kuychaco
